demographics.other: President of National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE) chapter

summaries.title: Leadership and Mentorship in Engineering Design Projects
summaries.summaryText: Aaliyah described how leading senior design teams strengthened her confidence in project management and technical problem-solving. She reflected on mentorship as a core component of her academic identity, often supporting younger women of color navigating engineering culture.

summaries.title: Representation and Visibility in Engineering Spaces
summaries.summaryText: She emphasized how few Black women were visible in faculty and leadership roles, describing representation as both motivating and emotionally taxing. Her NSBE involvement offered vital affirmation and a platform to advocate for equity.

summaries.title: Microaggressions and Invisible Labor in Group Dynamics
summaries.summaryText: Aaliyah recounted repeated experiences of having her technical input questioned in group settings. She also described taking on emotional labor to support other students facing similar bias.

timelinePoints.eventDescription: Co-founded a mentorship initiative within NSBE for first- and second-year engineering students.
Faced subtle exclusion in a group design project where her ideas were initially dismissed.
Presented senior capstone project on sustainable urban drainage systems, earning department recognition.

themes.title: Emotional Labor and Advocacy Burden in Underrepresented Students
themes.description: Aaliyah’s experience illustrates how women of color in engineering often balance advocacy roles with academic demands, leading to invisible emotional labor that institutions rarely acknowledge.

themes.title: Mentorship Networks as Retention Mechanisms
themes.description: Mentorship emerges as a consistent strategy for increasing belonging and persistence for students from marginalized groups. Aaliyah’s mentorship program demonstrates how peer-led initiatives can fill institutional gaps.

quotes.quoteText: I love leading projects, but it’s exhausting always being the one to explain why diversity matters in engineering teams.
quotes.context: Aaliyah describing the advocacy work tied to her leadership role.

quotes.quoteText: When I walk into a classroom and see no one who looks like me, I remind myself that my presence opens the door for someone else.
quotes.context: Aaliyah reflecting on the impact of representation and visibility.

quotes.quoteText: Mentorship is how we survive here — sharing what we’ve learned keeps us going when the system doesn’t always see us.
quotes.context: Aaliyah on the value of mentorship networks.

areasForImprovement.title: Formal Recognition for Student Advocacy and Mentorship Work
areasForImprovement.description: Students like Aaliyah contribute substantial unpaid labor in mentoring and advocacy roles. Institutions should recognize these contributions as part of leadership and service learning frameworks.
actionItems: Create service-learning credit for mentorship and advocacy roles
Include advocacy experience in leadership award criteria
